title: Qadry Ismail
text:
Qadry Rahmadan "The Missile" Ismail (born November 8, 1970) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a>. He was drafted by the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a> in the second round (52nd overall) of the <a href="1993%20NFL%20draft">1993 NFL draft</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Syracuse%20Orange%20football">Syracuse</a>.
He also played for the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a>, <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a>, <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a> (with which he won <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXV">Super Bowl XXXV</a>), and the <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a>.
Early years.
Qadry Rahmadan Ismail was born on November 8, 1970 in <a href="Newark%2C%20New%20Jersey">Newark, New Jersey</a>, the son of Ibrahim and Fat'ma Ismail. In 1985, he moved to his grandmother Laura Bauknight's home in <a href="Wilkes-Barre%2C%20Pennsylvania">Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania</a>, where he attended <a href="Elmer%20L.%20Meyers%20Junior/Senior%20High%20School">Elmer L. Meyers Junior/Senior High School</a>. There, Ismail and his older brother <a href="Raghib%20Ismail">Raghib</a>, were named the inaugural recipients of the <a href="Martin%20Luther%20King%20Jr.">Martin Luther King</a> Youth Leadership Award given by the local chapter of the <a href="NAACP">NAACP</a> of Northeast Pennsylvania. In addition to playing <a href="high%20school%20football">high school football</a>, Ismail also ran <a href="Track%20%26amp%3B%20field">track</a>.
As a member of the track team, he was ranked the nations best high school <a href="Hurdles">hurdler</a> by "<a href="Track%20%26amp%3B%20Field%20News">Track & Field News</a>" in 1988. He finished first at the 110m <a href="high%20hurdles">high hurdles</a> Golden West Invitational. He was also a two time state team champion in track and field. He was a six time <a href="Pennsylvania%20Interscholastic%20Athletic%20Association">PIAA</a> AA State champion in the 110m high hurdles, 300m intermediate hurdles, and <a href="4x100">4x100</a>. He was a two time PIAA AA silver medalist in the <a href="4x400">4x400</a>, as well as a bronze medalist in the 110m high hurdles. He was a four time PIAA District II team champion, and 12 time PIAA District II champion. He also earned two WVC team conference championships.
As a member of the football team, he was a two time All-scholastic selection as a wide receiver and <a href="defensive%20back">defensive back</a>. He was inducted into the PIAA Coaches Association Hall of Fame. He was named the 1988 Athlete of the Year by "<a href="The%20Citizens%27%20Voice">The Citizens' Voice</a>" and the "<a href="Times%20Leader">Times Leader</a>".
College career.
Ismail attended <a href="Syracuse%20University">Syracuse University</a>, where he was a member of the <a href="Syracuse%20Orange%20football">football</a> team as well as track team. Ismail was the first two sport All-American at Syracuse since <a href="Jim%20Brown">Jim Brown</a> in 1957.
As a member of the track team, Ismail was an All-American in the indoor 55m hurdles, as well as the outdoor 110m hurdles. He was also an IC4A 110m hurdle, and 55m hurdle champion. In addition to that, he the <a href="Big%20East">Big East</a> champion in the 110m hurdles, as well as the 55m hurdle and 4x400 <a href="Relay%20race">relay</a> while also setting Syracuse University’s school record in the 55m hurdles and the 4x400 relay.
As a member of the football team, Ismail was an All-American selection as a <a href="kick%20returner">kick returner</a> in <a href="1991%20Syracuse%20Orangemen%20football%20team">1991</a>. He was also a first team All-Big East selection as a wide receiver and kickoff returner, and a second team all-Big East selection as wide receiver.
Professional career.
Ismail was selected in the second round (52nd overall) of the <a href="1993%20NFL%20draft">1993 NFL draft</a> by the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a>, becoming the highest drafted Syracuse player since <a href="Art%20Monk">Art Monk</a>.
In 1999, he was voted Number 22 on the list of top 100 athletes by the "Citizen’s Voice".
In 1999 with the <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a>, Ismail led the team with 68 catches, 1,105 receiving yards and 6 touchdowns, including career-high 258 yards in one game against the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a>. What might have been the high-water mark of Ismail's career and potential crowning moment came on January 28, 2001, when the Baltimore Ravens defeated the <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a> 34-7 in <a href="Tampa%2C%20Florida">Tampa, Florida</a> in <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXV">Super Bowl XXXV</a>. Ismail caught a 47-yard reception and earned his first <a href="Super%20Bowl%20ring">Super Bowl ring</a>.
The next year, his final season in Baltimore, Ismail had his best season, leading the Ravens with 74 receptions and 7 touchdowns, both career-highs.
In 2002, Ismail signed a one-year deal with the <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> as a #2 <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a> behind <a href="Marvin%20Harrison">Marvin Harrison</a>.
Broadcast career.
After retiring from the NFL, Ismail began a career in broadcasting, spending time with <a href="Comcast%20Sports%20Net">Comcast Sports Net</a>, <a href="BET">BET</a> "<a href="College%20football%20on%20television%23Cable%20stations">Black College Football</a>", and <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> before becoming part of the Ravens’ broadcast team. In March 2017, it was announced that Ismail would be a <a href="color%20commentator">color commentator</a> for the <a href="Baltimore%20Brigade">Baltimore Brigade</a> of the <a href="Arena%20Football%20League">Arena Football League</a>.
Personal life.
Ismail is the brother of <a href="Raghib%20Ismail">Raghib "The Rocket" Ismail</a> and <a href="Sulaiman%20Ismail">Sulaiman "The Bomb" Ismail</a>. He has three children Qalea, Qadry, and Qadir from his marriage to Holly Oslander Ismail. Ismail is a sports performance coach (Missile Training) at the Sports Factory in Bel Air, Maryland. He has worked with hundreds of athletes helping them improve on their fitness and speed.
Ismail served as the head coach of the <a href="Patterson%20Mill%20High%20School">Patterson Mill High School</a> boys track and field team from 2011-2019. His daughter, Qalea, plays <a href="basketball">basketball</a> at <a href="Princeton%20University">Princeton University</a>. In 2017, his son, Qadry, began playing wide receiver at <a href="Mercyhurst%20University">Mercyhurst University</a>. In December 2017, his son, Qadir, signed to play <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> at <a href="Villanova%20Wildcats%20football">Villanova</a>.
